did.unittitle: Sylvia Hall Thompson Papers

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

did.abstract: This collection contains the papers of union organizer and Communist Party member Sylvia Hall Thompson (1924-2012). Thompson's papers primarily consists of Freedom of Information Act release files related to Federal Bureau of Investigation surveillance of Hall throughout the 1950s and 1960s. The collection also contains a small portion of material related to Sylvia's first huband Samuel Hall as well as material related to her second husband Robert George Thompson and the Thompson v. McNamara case.
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu at least two days prior to research visit.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Sylvia Hall Thompson (1924-2012) was born Sylvia Bernard in San Antonio, Texas. As a young woman, she joined the Communist Party and helped launch the Civil Rights Congress in Texas. In 1947, she traveled to North Carolina where she spent more than a year organizing electrical workers to join the union. It was there that she met her first husband, Sam Hall, a district organizer for the Party. The young couple moved to Birmingham, Alabama where, as open communists, they endured constant surveillance, threats and break-ins.

After Hall’s death, Sylvia moved to New York City where she went to work for the State Party office and met her second husband, Robert G. Thompson in late 1957. Bob Thompson had been a battalion commander with the Abraham Lincoln Brigade in Spain, and went on to receive one of the highest medals for valor – the Distinguished Service Cross – for his heroic actions in the Pacific Theater in World War II.

When he died in 1965, Sylvia sought and received permission from the Army to have his ashes interred in Arlington National Cemetery. However, when publicity about Bob’s previous imprisonment as a Smith Act defendant surfaced, the Army reversed itself and denied the widow’s request. Sylvia contested the Army's decision and in 1968, a federal appeals court ordered the Army to inter Bob Thompson’s ashes.

In subsequent years, Sylvia became a mainstay in the New York office of the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, working with veterans and organizing the annual reunions. Sylvia Thompson passed away in 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the papers of union organizer and Communist Party member Sylvia Hall Thompson. The majority of this collection relates to Sylvia's efforts to have her second husband Robert George Thompson interred in Arlington National Cemetery. A large portion of the collection also consists of Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) FBI Files on Sylvia Hall Thompson. See Series level scope and contents notes for further descriptions.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Sylvia Thompson bequeathed two boxes of her personal papers to Tamiment Library in 2013. The accession number associated with this gift is 2013.047. The Robert George Thompson Papers (previously TAM 075), which were also donated by Sylvia Thompson, were incorporated into this collection in 2014. The accession number associated with this material is 1950.142.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, materials were moved into archival housing, and a collection-level finding aid was created to describe these materials. No physical processing or arrangement was done at this time. The order in which these materials were sent to the Tamiment Library has been maintained. In 2014, the materials were found in repository and additional archival processing and description was completed. The Robert George Thompson Papers (previously TAM 075) were incorporated into this collection as Series III. A file level finding aid was created at this time.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright to materials in this collection created by the donor are held by the donor. Permission to publish or reproduce materials to which s/he holds copyright must be secured from the Tamiment Library and the copyright holder.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Sylvia Hall Thompson Papers; TAM 639; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

appraisal.head: Appraisal note
appraisal.p: No materials were separated from this collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into thrree series as follows:
Series I: Samuel Hall and Robert George Thompson Materials
Series II: Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) FBI Files on Sylvia Thompson
Series III: Thompson v. McNamara Trial Materials

did.unittitle: Series I: Samuel Hall and Robert George Thompson Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series I contains a small portion of material related to Sylvia's first husband Samuel Hall such as a marriage certificate, photographs, Sylvia Hall Thompson's reminisces of her husband, and clippings related to Hall's activism and his death in 1954. Material related to Robert Thompson includes a marriage certificate, correspondence, and photographs.This series also contains several articles by Robert Thompson, which were published in Political Affairs and materials related to Sylvia Hall Thompson's involvement with the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade.

did.unittitle: "New Apartment" [material relating to Samuel Hall including marriage certificate, death certificate and photographs]
Clippings, correspondence and writings pertaining to Robert Thompson and Arlington burial (includes Communist Party publications)
Materials relating to Robert Thompson's invovlement in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade (includes photographs and mandatory release form)
Facsimiles of original material pertaining to Robert Thompson's life and death [possibly trial exhibits]
FBI correspondence and excerpt of material Sylvia Thompson requested under FOIA
Marriage certificate (Sylvia and Robert Thompson) and death certificate of Robert Thompson
Photographs of Robert Thompson, Sylvia Thompson and others (includes Spanish Civil War songbook)
Brief of Appellant Thompson v. McNamara and Robert Thompson letter to Chairman of Soviet War Veteran's Committee
Letters from Robert Thompson to Sylvia Thompson
Series II: Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) FBI FIles on Sylvia Thompson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series II primarily consists of Freedom of Information Act release files related to Federal Bureau of Investigation surveillance of Hall throughout the 1950s and 1960s. Thompson requested copies of these files in the 1980s. Correspondence between Thompson and various government agencies is also included. Additionally, this series contains one cassette tape titled "Nuchow interview" and an encased coin commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Antifascist Spanish War.

Series III: Thompson v. McNamara Trial Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series III "Thompson v. McNamara" contains materials related to Sylvia Thompson's efforts to have her late husband interred in Arlington National Cemetery. It includes court documents exhibits and briefs, press clippings, photographs and correspondence. Also included is "The Arlington Case: Robert Thompson-story of an unburied soldier," which is a pamphlet published by Sylvia Thompson in 1967 in an effort to publicize her attempts at interring her husband in Arlington National Cemetery.
